Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of passive tactile learning gloves and associated systems for manual task learning and rehabilitation. Students’ and patients’ difficulties often stem from lack of time to practice or perform exercises. Slow and unclear progress leads to frustration and demotivation. Progress improvements through passive tactile stimulation may be evident through the use of personalized systems allowing users to customize and share lessons or therapy “session” sequences. Teachers or therapists provide “sessions” and feedback with the system, improving the lives of those unable to attend in-person sessions. Markets for manual task learning (piano, text entry) and rehabilitation aids (for stroke, spinal cord injury, cerebral palsy) span diverse demographics. The market for this technology is broad, for example, keyboarding is taught in grades 3 to 6 in over 40 states. In the US, 10 million adult survivors of stroke are estimated by 2030, with upper limb disability occurring in ~50% of cases. In addition, there are estimated to be 320,000 spinal cord injury (SCI) survivors. Globally, over 17 million people have cerebral palsy, with spasticity affecting 70 to 80%. This technology may assist in teaching and rehabilitation of these varied groups.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of passive tactile learning (PTL) Gloves for manual task learning and rehabilitation. This technology applies stimulation to the fingers throughout the day, eliciting a passive learning and/or passive rehabilitation effect. Until the development of PTL gloves, little research had been reported for passive learning through tactile stimulation. Most haptic learning of skills has been active. The PTL gloves are surprisingly effective at teaching novices new manual skills such as playing piano melodies, keying Morse code, number entry, or typing Braille. Stroke and partial spinal cord injury survivors using the PTL gloves have shown improvements in sensation, dexterity, and spasticity. Individuals with cerebral palsy also may benefit similarly and studies are currently underway. Questions remain as to the optimal schedule and combination of passive and active learning exposure so as to best assist new learners. In addition, passive tactile stimulation might be effective for rehabilitation for stroke, partial spinal cord injury, cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's, and a host of other illnesses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Until the Passive Tactile Learning (PTL) gloves, there has been little research reported in the literature of passive learning through tactile stimulation. Most haptic learning of skills has been active. The PTL gloves are surprisingly effective wearable devices used for teaching novices new manual skills such as playing piano melodies, keying Morse code, number entry, or typing Braille. This method has also shown promising preliminary results in hand rehabilitation after central nervous system traumatic injuries like, such as stroke and/or partial spinal cord injury. Learning manual tasks and rehabilitation are time consuming, and training learning/rehab programs can have less than a 5% adherence rate. Passive Tactile Learning gloves significantly accelerate skill learning and rehabilitation efforts by stimulating the user’s fingers throughout the day to train and teach the “muscle memory” of tasks without the user’s attention. For some critical skills, this accelerated learning may be the difference between independence and reliance on others. For example, only 10% of those who are blind learn Braille. The National Federation of the Blind calls this illiteracy a crisis as Braille literacy directly correlates with academic success and employment. In rehabilitation, motivation is a prime factor. Many traditional therapies involve strenuous monotonous exercises and are quickly abandoned, but playing piano can improve dexterity as well as mental well-being. PTL gloves both may directly improve hand sensation and dexterity and inspire users to continue rehab in the form of piano playing as a hobby.

However, questions remain as to the optimal schedule and combination of passive and active learning exposure that would best assist learners. Manual skills, such as synchronized, dual-hand instruction, are most desired, which would be a good goal to address by PTL methods. Similarly, passive tactile stimulation might be effective for rehabilitation for stroke, partial spinal cord injury, cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis, Parkinsons, ALS, and a host of other illnesses. PTL integrated therapies may improve responses to various degrees, but how might the treatment be best delivered for adherence and efficacy?

The I-Corp interview process reveals students’ and patients’ difficulties, which often stem from lack of time and motivation to practice or perform exercises. These findings are reinforced by music teachers, academics, and industry professionals. Slow and unclear progress leads to frustration and demotivation. However, when students are able to clearly see that their efforts result in learning progress, they are more willing to continue to adhere to their practice schedules, leading to life-long learning. Improvements in learning or rehabilitation progress through passive tactile stimulation would be evident with use of a personalized learning progress dashboard, where users customize and share lessons or therapy “session” sequences, improving learning and rehabilitation outcomes. Teachers or therapists provide “sessions” and feedback on student progress, improving the lives of those unable to attend in-person sessions.

Markets for manual task learning (piano, text entry) and rehabilitation (stroke, spinal cord injury, cerebral palsy) aids span diverse demographics. People learning instruments, who are willing to use apps (and subscribe) or other learning software/systems total 400 million subscribers, or 200 million active users, in the US. Keyboarding is taught in grades 3 to 6 in over 40 states. In the US, there are estimated to be 10 million adult survivors of stroke by 2030, with upper limb disability occuring in ~50% of cases. There are estimated to be 320,000 spinal cord injury (SCI) survivors, with 17,700 new cases each year. Globally, over 17 million people have cerebral palsy, with spasticity affecting 70 to 80%. Stroke and partial SCI survivors using the PTL gloves have shown improvements in sensation, dexterity, and spasticity, and we believe cerebral palsy may be affected by similar mechanisms.

Through the I-Corps customer discovery process, the narrowed market segment of focus to beginning piano learners provided an avenue to explore, in depth, the potential for PTL Gloves to improve the learning process. Interviews with professionals in the consumer device, music technology, and education industries provided insights into the potential pitfalls related to manufacturing, marketing, and licensing, as well as opportunities for potential partnerships that may lead to synergistic developments with educational and musical app developers. 

The key findings that would provide value to learners (and potentially to those pursuing rehabilitation) would be the ability to see a reduction in the need for active practice time, while maintaining similar levels of progress; increasing their ability to perform songs or everyday functions with less overall effort; to provide a greater sense of capability, thus increasing motivation to continue the PTL process; and to provide additional avenues for learners to interact with teachers or rehab specialists, which would especially help those without the means to attend such sessions in person.
